details.overview: If you are responsible for at least one child, you may be eligible for Child Tax Credit - what you might get, how to claim, information if your child is disabled

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You could qualify for Child Tax Credit if you are responsible for at least one child or young person who normally lives with you. These are payments made to the person who is mainly responsible for the child or children.

Who can claim

You can usually claim for:

  • any child living with you - until 31 August after their 16th birthday
  • children or young people under 20, if they’re in certain types of education or training

In most cases the total annual income limits for tax credits are:

You have one child £26,000
You have 2 children £32,200
Single without children £13,000
Couple without children £18,000

These are the limits for getting tax credits in the current tax year - ending on 5 April 2013.

The income limits don’t apply to everyone - they could be higher if for example you have:

  • a large family and pay a lot in childcare
  • a disability
  • a disabled child

Check if you qualify - use this quick online questionnaire.

What you could get

To find out what you could get, use the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) tax credits calculator.

Backdating your claim

Claims can normally be backdated by one month, check backdating your tax credits claim to see if it will be done automatically or if you need to let the Tax Credit Office know.

How to claim

Check if you are also eligible for Working Tax Credit as you can claim both using the same form.

You don’t need to make a new claim if you are already getting tax credits. Call the Tax Credit Helpline to update your claim.

Elements of Child Tax Credit

The table below shows the Child Tax Credit elements you could get and the maximum yearly payments.

The payments apply whether or not you work.

Elements What it is Max yearly amount
family (basic) element basic payment if you qualify for Child Tax Credit £545
child paid on top of the basic element for each of your children £2,690
disabled child paid for each disabled child £2,950
severely disabled child paid on top of the disabled child element for each severely disabled child £1,190

parts.title: Your child is disabled
parts.body:
If your child has a disability you may qualify for extra Child Tax Credit.

Who is eligible?

You qualify if any of the following apply:

  • Disability Living Allowance is paid for your child
  • your child is registered blind
  • your child came off the blind register in the 28 weeks before you claimed tax credits

You can still qualify if the Disability Living Allowance stops because your child goes into hospital.

If the Highest Rate Care Component of Disability Living Allowance is paid for your child, you may get an additional payment for their severe disability.

What you’ll get

The amount of you get depends on your income and how much care your child needs.

You could get up to approximately:

Your child is disabled £53 a week £2,800 a year
Your child is severely disabled £75 a week £3,930 a year

To find out what tax credits you could get overall, use the online calculator.

How to claim

If you are not currently getting tax credits, you need to fill in a claim form. You can’t apply online.

If you are already getting tax credits, call the Tax Credit Helpline to amend your claim. You should do this as soon as you know that Disability Living Allowance (or the Highest Rate Care Component) will be paid for your child.

Contact the helpline within 3 months to get your payments backdated.

parts.title: Adoptive or foster parents
parts.body:
You can claim if you’re not getting any money from your:

  • local authority
  • Health and Social Services Board

If you are getting money from either of these, call the Tax Credit Helpline to find out if you can claim.

parts.title: Your child lives with more than one person
parts.body:
Only one household can get Child Tax Credit for a child.

If your child lives with more than one person you’ll have to decide who should get it.

You can’t claim Child Tax Credit if your child doesn’t live with you at all - even if you’re paying maintenance.

You can’t agree who’ll claim

If you can’t agree who’ll get the Child Tax Credit, both of you should claim for the child. Your payments will stay the same until The Tax Credit Office makes a decision. They’ll contact both of you to work out who has main responsibility for the child. They will consider things that include the number of days the child lives with you, and where they keep most of their clothes and toys.

You’re already getting tax credits for your child

Someone else might make a claim for a child you’re getting Child Tax Credit for. If this happens, the Tax Credit Office may ask you to tell them why you think you have main responsibility for that child.

parts.title: You’re not the child’s parent
parts.body:
You can claim Child Tax Credit if you have responsibility for a child. For example, this could be if:

  • the child usually lives with you
  • the child keeps their toys, clothes and other items at your home
  • you pay for their meals and give them pocket money

There can be exceptions to this, for example, if a child from abroad lives with you as an exchange student.

If you’re not sure whether you count as being responsible for a child you can call the Tax Credit Helpline for advice.

parts.title: Changes you need to report
parts.body:
Changes to report as soon as possible

Tell the Tax Credit Office if:

  • you start looking after a child
  • your child stays on in education or training that counts for Child Tax Credit after they reach 16

Changes to report within one month

Tell the Tax Credit Office within one month if your child:

  • goes to live with someone else
  • dies
  • leaves full-time education or approved training that counts for Child Tax Credit
  • starts training that’s provided as part of their job
  • gets a paid job and they’re usually paid to work for 24 hours or more a week - and they’ve left education or training that counts for Child Tax Credit
  • starts to claim benefits or tax credits in their own right

If you don’t report these changes, you might be paid too much in tax credits. If the Tax Credit Office does overpay you, you’ll usually have to pay the money back. They may also charge you a penalty.

Changes to report within 3 months

Tell the Tax Credit Office if your child is 16 or 17 and both of the following apply:

  • they stop education or training that counts for Child Tax Credit
  • they register with a careers service - like Connexions

If you don’t, you could lose out on an extra period of Child Tax Credit of up to 20 weeks.
